citeinfo.origin: Foufoula-Georgiou, Efi, Chris Paola, Michal Tal, and Elizabeth Tilman
citeinfo.title: Riparian Vegetation and Braided Stream Dynamics

descript.abstract: Goal: 1. To study and quantify the interactions between riparian vegetation, channel morphology, and flow dynamics. 2. To investigate how river systems self-organize as a result of these interactions. 3. To investigate spatial and dynamic scaling in braided rivers with and without vegetation. Reseachers: Michal Tal, Chris Paola, Elizabeth Tilman (Water Resources, Univ. of MN), Efi Foufoula-Georgiou (Civil Engineering, Univ. of MN) Result: Ongoing experiments at the St. Anthony Falls Laboratory are designed to isolate the effects of vegetation on braided stream dynamics. These experiments show how a fully braided stream with a noncohesive bed transitions to a single-thread (meandering) system when continuously forced with vegetation. Time-lapse photography and measurements of bed topography, flow depth, sediment output, and flow velocities enable us to study and quantify the morphodynamics of the system associated with this change.

idinfo.datacred: This work was supported by the Science and Technology Center program of the National Science Foundation (NSF) via the National Center for Earth-surface Dynamics under Agreement Number EAR-0120914. We are grateful to the staff at the St Anthony Falls Laboratory for help with experiments. We thank Murray Hicks, Gary Parker, and Bill Dietrich for stimulating and helpful discussions. We greatly appreciate the insightful comments by Maarten Kleinhans and an anonymous reviewer. M. Tal was funded through a Chateaubriand Science Fellowship and a postdoctoral position at the Institute de Physique du Globe de Paris (IPGP) while writing this paper and thanks the Geomorphology group at IPGP for their support and for providing a stimulating work environment.
